100.description: An introduction to problems of the comparative study of literature and culture. Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and analysis with focus on selected literary, critical, and theoretical texts from antiquity to the present. Readings in English and at least one foreign language.
100.title: Introduction to Comparative Literature

201.description: This course is designed to give all new graduate students a broad view of the department's faculty, the courses they teach, and their fields of research. In addition, it will introduce students to some practical aspects of the graduate career, issues that pertain to specific fields of research, and questions currently being debated across the profession. The readings for the course will consist of copies of materials by the department's faculty.
201.title: Proseminar

375.description: Discussion of the theory and practice of teaching composition at the college level in a department of comparative literature.
375.title: Methods of Teaching Literature and English Composition-Comparative Literature

223.description: Comparative investigation of major themes in nineteenth-century literature and culture.
223.title: Studies in the 19th Century

R1B.description: Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature. R1A satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R1B satisfies the second half.
R1B.title: English Composition in Connection with the Reading of World Literature

212.description: Comparative investigation of a topic in literature and culture between the fifth and the fourteenth centuries.
212.title: Studies in Medieval Literature

190.description: Seminar-style treatment of a major topic in Comparative Literature. Substantial paper required.
190.title: Senior Seminar in Comparative Literature

R1A.description: Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature. R1A satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R1B satisfies the second half.
R1A.title: English Composition in Connection with the Reading of World Literature

254.description: Comparative investigation of a literary topic requiring the study of both East Asian and Western documents.
254.title: Studies in East-West Literary Relations

240.description: Comparative study of the historical and systematic relations between literature and other arts such as the visual arts, music, and film.
240.title: Studies in the Relations Between Literature and the Other Arts

171.description: This course frames methodologically selected topics in Modern Greek Literature and places them in their historical, social or cultural context.
171.title: Topics in Modern Greek Literature

260.description: Theory and practice of translation. Students will complete a project in literary translation.
260.title: Problems in Literary Translation

24.description: The Freshman Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. Freshman seminars are offered in all campus departments and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester. Enrollment limited to fifteen freshmen.
24.title: Freshman Seminar

270.description: Discussion on problems of the literature of the period.
270.title: Continuing Seminars

112A.description: Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar and syntax studied. The forms of writing (prose, poetry, drama) and the reading of literary texts as auxiliary to the acquisition of compositional skills.
112A.title: Modern Greek Language and Modern Greek Composition

H195.description: Preparation and writing of an honors thesis under the supervision of a member of the faculty.
H195.title: Honors Course

270E.description: Discussion on problems of the literature of the period.
270E.title: Continuing Seminars: Modern

298.description: Primarily for students engaged in preliminary exploration of a restricted field, involving the writing of a report. May not be substituted for available seminars.
298.title: Special Study

20.description: An introductory level exploration of a specific author, work, theme or literary movement in an international context. Emphasis on the ways in which literature has played (and continues to play) a crucial role in the relationship between different cultures, traditions, and languages. Readings and topics to vary from semester to semester.
20.title: Episodes in Literary Cultures

300.description: Course credit for experience gained in academic teaching through employment as a graduate student instructor.
300.title: Supervised Teaching in Comparative Literature

198.description: Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of any regular course and must be specific enough to enable students to write essays based upon their studies.
198.title: Directed Group Study

60AC.description: Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics will vary from semester to semester, but may include such themes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult the department's course bulletin well before the beginning of the semester for details.
60AC.title: Topics in the Literature of American Cultures

98.description: Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of any regular course and must be specific enough to enable students to write essays based upon their studies.
98.title: Directed Group Study for Freshmen and Sophomores

200.description: Lectures on literary theory, on the study of criticism, and on the methods of comparative literary theory.
200.title: Approaches to Comparative Literature
